items.title: An introduction to federal website standards
items.deck: Understand how and why to use the federal website standards
items.summary: The federal website standards help agencies provide high-quality, consistent digital experiences for everyone. They cover common visual technical elements and reflect user experience best practices.

items.title: Hurricane Milton guidance for U.S. government websites and social media
items.deck: Addressing web and digital communications related to Hurricane Milton
items.summary: Addressing web and digital communications related to Hurricane Milton

items.title: An introduction to multilingual glossaries
items.deck: Understand how and why to use a multilingual glossary when translating content
items.summary: Learn how to use multilingual glossaries to share common translations and contribute to consistent communication across government.

items.title: Hurricane Helene guidance for U.S. government websites and social media
items.deck: Addressing web and digital communications related to Hurricane Helene
items.summary: Addressing web and digital communications related to Hurricane Helene

items.title: How to conduct a project reflection
items.deck: A template for ending projects
items.summary: Use this template, shared at the 2024 Spring Community Summit, to improve your own service delivery.

items.title: How to transition a team off of a project
items.deck: A template for transitioning projects to another team
items.summary: Use this template, shared at the 2024 Spring Community Summit, to improve your own service delivery.

items.title: Requirements for strengthening the federal government's commitment to digital accessibility
items.deck: Understand the policy framework: Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, Section 508 Standards, and OMB Memo M-24-08
items.summary: Learn how to implement Section 508, and strengthen and maintain your agency’s commitment to digital accessibility.

items.title: An introduction to customer experience
items.deck: Improving customer experience (CX) drives better performance in the federal government
items.summary: Understand what customer experience (CX) is and how to leverage customer feedback and analytics to enhance the public’s experience when interacting with government services.

items.title: Requirements for the registration and use of .gov domains in the federal government
items.deck: Understand the policy framework: DOTGOV Online Trust in Government Act and OMB Memo M-23-10
items.summary: Learn how to implement the DOTGOV Online Trust in Government Act and understand how to register federal internet domain names.

items.title: Requirements for improving access to services for people with limited English proficiency (LEP)
items.deck: Understand the policy framework: Executive Order 13166, Attorney General memorandum, and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act
items.summary: Learn how to strengthen and improve meaningful language access for all people in the U.S., regardless of the language they speak.

items.title: An introduction to the Digital Experience Council
items.deck: A cross-agency group designed for delivering a digital-first public experience
items.summary: The Digital Experience (DX) Council plays a critical role in coordinating governmentwide efforts and assisting agencies in delivering digital experiences that meet the public’s needs and expectations.

items.title: Social media cyber-vandalism toolkit
items.deck: How to prepare for, recover from, and respond to cyber incidents
items.summary: Cyber-vandalism presents a serious challenge to online-based communication tools. This resource provides information for agency practitioners to prepare for, recover from, and respond to cyber-vandalism.

items.title: Requirements for improving the management of federal programs and projects
items.deck: Understand the policy framework: Program Management Improvement Accountability Act and OMB Memo M-18-19
items.summary: Learn how to implement the Program Management Improvement Accountability Act to deliver better websites and digital services.

items.title: An introduction to working with social media influencers
items.deck: How to create and manage a social media influencer program
items.summary: Learn how to partner with social media influencers and  design, implement, and measure an influencer program.

items.title: An introduction to content
items.deck: Understand why content matters to digital experience
items.summary: Best practices for creating clear, useful, digital content for federal websites and digital services.

items.title: An introduction to inclusion
items.deck: Understand why and how to create an inclusive culture
items.summary: An inclusive culture contributes to a sense of belonging, promotes a healthier and more empowering workplace, respects differences, and optimizes for equal opportunities.

items.title: An introduction to web security
items.deck: Understand how security impacts your website
items.summary: Guidance on meeting security requirements for federal websites.

items.title: An introduction to privacy
items.deck: Understand privacy requirements for agency websites
items.summary: Introductory guidance on implementing privacy protections for users of federal websites.

items.title: An introduction to analytics
items.deck: Use metrics and data to understand how people use your website
items.summary: Learn how to set performance goals, and identify specific KPIs and targets to measure and meet them, using web analytics.

items.title: An introduction to structured content
items.deck: Understand the benefits of structuring digital content
items.summary: Publishing content as modular pieces of information that are tagged with machine-readable descriptions can transform how people find, understand, share, use, and reuse government information.

items.title: An introduction to ATOs
items.deck: Understand the authority to operate process
items.summary: What is an Authorization to Operate? Before you use software in government, you need to make sure it is allowed. You should know what an ATO is, and when you need one.

items.title: An introduction to security and privacy controls
items.deck: Explaining NIST’s 800-53 control families for information systems and organizations
items.summary: What do the control families of NIST 800-53 mean? Here’s an overview of the control families that create the foundation of federal security compliance.

items.title: An introduction to trust
items.deck: Understand how digital services impact trust in government
items.summary: Guidance on how to build government websites that people can trust.

items.title: An introduction to design
items.deck: Understand how to implement a design-driven user experience
items.summary: How to design government websites that meet customer needs, work well on any device, and follow federal web requirements.

items.title: An introduction to pronouns
items.deck: Understand how and why to use pronouns
items.summary: A guide for government employees and contractors to understand and use pronouns in the workplace.

items.title: Introduction to translation technology
items.deck: How and why to use translation technology to create multilingual content
items.summary: What is translation technology? This introductory resource will help you understand how and when to use translation technology to provide meaningful access for people with limited English proficiency.

items.title: An introduction to plain language
items.deck: Using plain language is required on all government websites and also creates a better user experience.
items.summary: Understand how and why to use plain language on government websites and other digital services

items.title: How to start and sustain a federal podcast
items.deck: It seems like everyone has a podcast these days, including the federal government. Should your agency decide to do the same — and if so, how do you even get started?
items.summary: Discover how to create and maintain a successful podcast at your federal agency.

items.title: An introduction to design systems
items.deck: Learn how and why to use design systems
items.summary: If your organization needs to ensure compliance with a design standard or align to a brand, a design system can help you achieve those goals more easily than building a site from scratch. Learn how a design system can help you and what you need to know to get started.

items.title: Introduction to QR codes
items.deck: How and why to use QR codes to bridge the online and offline worlds
items.summary: What is a QR code and how can you create one? What are some alternatives to using QR codes? This introductory resource will help you explore your options.

items.title: Introduction to self-description
items.deck: How and why to create self-descriptions when you introduce yourself during events and presentations
items.summary: Help create inclusive digital spaces with these tips for using self-descriptions in virtual meetings or conference calls.

items.title: Embedding Equity in Civic Design to Transform Customer Experience
items.summary: This case study describes how two civic designers at different agencies embed equity in civic design to transform federal customer experience.

items.title: Lessons from the 2021 Federal Plain Language Report Card

items.summary: This event recap highlights best practices, a short case study video, and examples of federal web content that received both high and low scores in the 2021 Plain Language Report Card.

items.title: Multilingual Huddle: Designing for Translation
items.summary: In this webinar, Laura Godfrey and Fedora Braverman share tips for translating content in the digital context.

items.title: How to Present Like a Pro

items.summary: Wendy Wagner-Smith of the Small Business Administration (SBA) shares her tips and tricks for presenting virtually.

items.summary: A case study using Digital.gov as an example of how to assess, report, and take action using web analytics as part of an analytics strategy.

items.summary: In conjunction with her May 2020 presentation, Dr. Emily Shen outlines her work on Secure multi-party computation (MPC), a type of cryptography that allows parties to jointly analyze their data without disclosing it.

items.summary: A .gov domain instantly conveys credibility and trustworthiness, and proper domain management practices ensure that your website is secure and accessible.

items.title: Implementation of the Government Paperwork Elimination Act
items.summary: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) provided this guidance to implement the Government Paperwork Elimination Act (GPEA). GPEA required Federal agencies, by October 21, 2003, to allow individuals or entities that deal with the agencies the option to submit information or transact with the agency electronically, when practicable, and to maintain records electronically, when practicable.

items.title: 2012 Digital Government Strategy
items.summary: The Digital Government Strategy complements several initiatives aimed at building a 21st century government that works better for the American people.

items.title: Requirements for Accepting Externally Issued Identity Credentials
items.summary: This memo dated October 6, 2011, from the Federal CIO to the CIO’s of Executive Departments and Agencies, mandates that agencies are to begin leveraging externally-issued credentials, in addition to continuing to offer federally-issued credentials.

items.title: OMB Final Guidance on Implementing the Plain Writing Act of 2010 (M-11-15)
items.summary: Provides final guidance on implementing the Plain Writing Act of 2010 and is designed to promote the goals of the president’s Open Government Initiative.

items.title: OMB Memo on Testing and Simplifying Federal Forms
items.summary: View or download the OMB Memo on Testing and Simplifying Federal Forms

items.title: Open Data Policy (M-13-13)
items.summary: This Memorandum establishes a framework to help institutionalize the principles of effective information management at each stage of the information’s life cycle to promote interoperability and openness.

items.title: Making Open and Machine Readable the New Default for Government Information
items.summary: Openness in government strengthens our democracy, promotes the delivery of efficient and effective services to the public, and contributes to economic growth. As one vital benefit of open government, making information resources easy to find, accessible, and usable can fuel entrepreneurship, innovation, and scientific discovery that improves Americans’ lives and contributes significantly to job creation.

items.title: Guidance for Implementing the Privacy Provisions of the E–Government Act of 2002 (M-03–22)
items.summary: This guidance provides information to agencies on implementing the privacy provisions of the E-Government Act of 2002. It addresses privacy protections when Americans interact with their government.

items.title: GOV Domain Registration Process Final Rule
items.summary: This final rule provided a new policy for the .gov domain that will be included in the Federal Management Regulation.

items.title: Digital Millennium Copyright Act
items.summary: The Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) is a United States copyright law that implements two 1996 treaties of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO). Passed on October 12, 1998, the DMCA amended Title 17 of the United States Code to extend the reach of copyright, while limiting the liability of the providers of online services

items.title: U.S. Trademark Law
items.summary: United States trademark law is mainly governed by the Lanham Act. “Common law” trademark rights are acquired automatically when a business uses a name or logo in commerce, and are enforceable in state courts. Marks registered with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office are given a higher degree of protection in federal courts than unregistered

items.title: Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. 3501 et seq.)
items.summary: The Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) of 1995 requires that agencies obtain Office of Management and Budget (OMB) approval before requesting most types of information from the public.

items.title: Guidance on the Use of Challenges and Prizes to Promote Open Government
items.summary: This guidance calls for the increased use of challenges and prizes to develop new tools and approaches to improve open government, and highlights for agencies policy and legal issues related to the use of prizes and challenges as tools for promoting open government, innovation, and other national priorities.

items.title: Circular A-130 Revised
items.summary: Circular A-130 was first issued in December 1985 to meet information resource management requirements that were included in the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) of 1980. Specifically, the PRA assigned responsibility to the OMB Director to develop and maintain a comprehensive set of information resources management policies for use across the Federal government, and to promote

items.title: Quick Reference to Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 2.0 requirements
items.summary: This quick reference guide will help you meet Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.0. It is a customizable quick reference to the requirements, success criteria and techniques.

items.title: Guidelines for Secure Use of Social Media
items.summary: Guidelines and recommendations for using social media technologies in a manner that minimizes risks are analyzed and presented in this document.

items.title: Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 – Presentation to the 2003 FISSEA Conference
items.summary: The head of the agency delegates to the CIO a number of information security responsibilities. The CIO in turn designates a senior agency information security officer.

items.title: Guidelines on Securing Public Web Servers
items.summary: The World Wide Web (WWW) is a system for exchanging information over the Internet. At the most basic level, the Web can be divided into two principal components: Web servers, which are applications that make information available over the Internet (in essence, publish information), and Web browsers (clients), which are used to access and display.

items.title: FY 2004 Reporting Instructions for the Federal Information Security Management Act
items.summary: This memorandum provides updated instructions for agency reporting under the Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 (FISMA). Agency Chief Information Officers and Inspectors General have also received a copy of the attached instructions. View FY 2004 Reporting Instructions for the Federal Information Security Management Act Related Links OMB M-04-15 Reporting Instructions for the

items.title: NARA guidance on Managing Web Records
items.summary: Managing web records properly is essential to effective web site operations, especially the mitigation of the risks an agency faces by using the web to carry out agency business.

items.title: Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Parts 1220-1238
items.summary: Subchapter B  of the CFR specifies polices for federal agencies records management programs relating to proper records creation and maintenance, adequate documentation, and records disposition. View Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Parts 1220-1238 Related Links NARA guidance for implementing Section 207(e) of the E-Gov Act NARA guidance on managing web records NARA Bulletin 2014-02 Guidance

items.title: Children’s Online Privacy Protection Rule (“COPPA”)
items.summary: The Children’s Online Privacy Protection Rule,imposes certain requirements on operators of websites or online services directed to children under 13 years of age, and on operators of other websites or online services that have actual knowledge that they are collecting personal information online from a child under 13 years of age.

items.title: Appendix I to OMB Circular No. A-130 Federal Agency Responsibilities for Maintaining Records About Individuals
items.summary: This Appendix describes agency responsibilities for implementing the reporting and publication requirements of the Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. 552a. It applies to all agencies subject to the Act. View Appendix I to OMB Circular No. A-130 Federal Agency Responsibilities for Maintaining Records About Individuals Related Resources OMB M-15-13, Policy to Require Secure Connections

items.title: Guidance for Agency Use of Third-Party Websites and Applications
items.summary: This Memorandum requires Federal agencies to take specific steps to protect individual privacy whenever they use third-party websites and applications to engage with the public.

items.title: Open Government Directive
items.summary: This memorandum is intended to direct executive departments and agencies to take specific actions to implement the principles of transparency, participation, and collaboration set forth in the President’s Memorandum on Transparency and Open Government. This Directive was informed by recommendations from the Federal Chief Technology Officer, who solicited public comment through the White House Open

items.title: No FEAR Act
items.summary: The No FEAR Act requires a Federal agency to post on its public Web site summary statistical data pertaining to complaints of employment discrimination filed under 29 CFR part 1614 by employees, former employees and applicants for employment. View NO FEAR Act See more DigitalGov Resources

items.title: Guidance on President’s Management Agenda Scorecard Meetings
items.summary: This memorandum provides Resource Management Offices and PMA Initiative Leads with instructions for preparing for the quarterly PMA scorecard meetings to discuss agencies’ status and progress in implementing the PMA for the period January 1, 2008 through March 31, 2008. View Guidance on President’s Management Agenda Scorecard Meetings See more DigitalGov Resources

items.title: Social Media, Web-Based Interactive Technologies, and the Paperwork Reduction Act
items.summary: This memo clarifies when and how the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995 (the PRA) applies to federal agency use of social media and web-based interactive technologies.

items.title: Executive Order 13571–Streamlining Service Delivery and Improving Customer Service
items.summary: The Executive Order 13571 on Streamlining Service Delivery and Improving Customer Service “requires agencies that provide significant services directly to the public to identify and survey their customers, establish service standards and track performance against those standards, and benchmark customer service performance against the best in business.” View Executive Order 13571–Streamlining Service Delivery and Improving Customer Service

items.title: M-11-24 Implementing Executive Order 13571 on Streamlining Service Delivery and Improving Customer Service
items.summary: Memo M-11-24 is guidance to Implement Executive Order 13571.

items.title: M-10-22 Guidance for Online Use of Web Measurement and Customization Technologies
items.summary: On January 21, 2009, the President issued a memorandum calling for the establishment of “a system of transparency, public participation, and collaboration.” The memorandum required an Open Government Directive to be issued by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), instructing “executive departments and agencies to take specific actions implementing the principles

items.title: M-11-26 New Fast-Track Process for Collecting Service Delivery Feedback Under the Paperwork Reduction Act
items.summary: The new Paperwork Reduction Act Fast Track Process  will allow agencies to obtain timely feedback on service delivery while ensuring that the information collected is useful and minimally burdensome for the public, as required by the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995.

items.title: Plain Writing Act of 2010
items.summary: The law requires that federal agencies provide clear communication about government information and services for the public.

items.title: Federal Plain Language Guidelines
items.summary: The Plain Language Action and Information Network (PLAIN) put together these federal guidelines to help implement the Plain Language Act of 2010.

items.summary: The 2012 Digital Government Strategy mission drives agencies, and the need to deliver better services to customers at a lower cost.

items.title: E-Gov Act of 2002
items.summary: The E-Government Act of 2002 (Pub.L. 107–347, 116 Stat. 2899, 44 U.S.C. § 101, H.R. 2458/S. 803), is a United States statute enacted on December 17, 2002, with an effective date for most provisions of April 17, 2003. Its stated purpose is to improve the management and promotion of electronic government services and processes by

items.title: Freedom of Information Act Memo 2009
items.summary: The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) is the law that gives anyone the right to access information from the federal government. items.title: Improving the Accessibility of Social Media in Government
items.summary: Government agencies are increasingly using social media to engage with citizens, share information and deliver services more quickly and effectively than ever before. items.summary: The Contact Center is no longer viewed as only a center to receive complaints, but as a valued operation in an agency’s strategy to deliver a quality customer experience.

items.title: Paperwork Reduction Act Fast Track Process
items.summary: Protect Your Customer’s Privacy Federal agencies must follow various laws and regulations, including the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) and the Privacy Act, when collecting information from the public. You should also be familiar with SORN (Systems of Records Notice), as well as rules around personally identifiable information, and laws that relate to your specific method of feedback collection

items.title: Agency Points of Contact for Federal Compatible Terms of Service Agreements

items.summary: The list of cabinet and non-cabinet agency points of contact for the federal-compatible Terms of Service agreements.

items.title: Mobile User Experience Guidelines
items.deck: Six user experience guidelines for creating a mobile product.
items.summary: These mobile user experience guidelines were distilled from community feedback about mobile UX practices.

items.title: DigitalGov User Experience Resources
items.summary: DigitalGov’s user experience resources provide tools for federal employees on how to make products and services more user-friendly, save money via user research, and create successful experiences.

items.title: Using the do and don'ts table
items.summary: What to do and what not to do, that is the question

items.title: Mobile SOW and Developer Qualifications
items.summary: Structuring a Statement of Work (SOW) for the development or modification of mobile products should be similar to any SOW your government organization issues for IT products and services.

items.title: Mobile Application Development Program
items.summary: Helping agencies plan, develop, test and launch anytime, anywhere, any device mobile products and services for the public. Plan—Build a mobile strategy, see what other agencies have done, use new acquisitions tools to find top mobile developers. Develop—Create great mobile apps and sites
